title: Tornado tears through Dallas, leaving thousands without power
text:
Tornado tears through Dallas, leaving thousands without power originally appeared on abcnews.go.com

At least one tornado touched down in the Dallas area amid stormy weather on Sunday night, tearing through structures, overturning cars and knocking out electricity for thousands.

The National Weather Service said the radar-confirmed the tornado hit the ground around 9 p.m. local time near Dallas Love Field Airport, northwest of downtown. Footage from the area showed several damaged businesses, homes with the roofs ripped off, fallen trees and downed power lines.

The Dallas Independent School District canceled Monday classes at six schools, citing "extensive damage" to a number of campuses due to the severe weather.

There were also reports of gas leaks north of Dallas' Walnut Hill neighborhood, according to a press release from the city of Dallas.

(MORE: New storm to bring possible tornadoes and damaging winds across the South)

PHOTO: A tornado is seen in north Dallas, Texas, on Oct. 20, 2019, in this screen grab obtained from a social media video. (Philip Ellis/PHILIP ELLIS via Reuters) More

Rocky Vaz, the director of the City of Dallas Office of Emergency Management, said six people were transported to local hospitals but were not seriously injured. However, there were no reports of deaths or serious injuries as of early Monday morning, according to the city.

Nearly 151,000 electric customers were without power as of 5:30 a.m. local time, according to Oncor Electric Delivery Company's online outage map. About 65,000 of those customers were within Dallas, according to the city, which opened the Bachman Recreation Center early Monday morning for people seeking shelter.

The Dallas Police Department and Dallas Fire-Rescue are assessing the damage.

(MORE: Controlled demolition takes down 1 crane looming over New Orleans Hard Rock Hotel)

PHOTO: In this Oct. 20, 2019, photo offered by Lew Morris, damage to the Reckless Rock Radio station studio is seen after a tornado touched down in Dallas, Texas. (Lew Morris/AP) More

In the city of Sachse, a northeast suburb of Dallas, six houses sustained "significant high-wind damage after severe weather moved through the area Sunday night," and four of those homes were left "uninhabitable," though no injuries had been reported, according to a press release from the city.

Meanwhile, two tornadoes were reported near the city of Tyler, about 100 miles southeast of Dallas.

A tornado watch remains in effect for eastern Texas as residents brace for another storm Monday morning.

ABC News' Alexandra Faul, Max Golembo and Jennifer Watts contributed to this report.
description: The National Weather Service said the radar-confirmed the tornado hit the ground around 9 p.m. local time near Dallas Love Field Airport, northwest of downtown.  The Dallas Independent School District canceled Monday classes at six schools, citing "extensive damage" to a number of campuses
